p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end; font-style: italic;

div.p:
To proof.
Victorian Commission for the Calcutta

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end; font-style: italic;

div.p: International Exhibition, 1883-84.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end; font-variant: small-caps;

div.p: Offices: Treasury Building, Spring Street,
Melbourne , April 19th 1883.
Sir/

I have the honour to enclose herewith a communication received from Mr W. R. Guilfoyle,
Guilfoyle's letter, dated 16 April 1883, is enclosed in the file. director of the Melbourne Botanic Gardens, on the subject of the steps to be taken in relation to a collection of the vegetable products of Victoria being formed for the Calcutta International Exhibition. Having always manifested interest in the development of our indigenous products, I am particularly desirous that advantage should be taken of the present opportunity to make a good display in India, and I may therefore be pardoned for impressing upon you the advantages which may be derived from the exercise of a little liberality in the matter.

2. — To make a thorough collection embracing not only seeds, dried specimens of plants, woods, and fibres, but living plants — such as ferns, todeas, &c would, according to Mr Guilfoyle's estimate, involve an expenditure of £250. As the object of being represented at Calcutta is twofold, viz — to illustrate the resources of this colony and to bring back information regarding India and its products — the value of sending collections which could be exchanged for seeds of Indian plants and products likely to prove of practical benefit to the people of Victoria will be readily admitted.

3. — Dealing with Mr Guilfoyle's suggestions in the order in which they are made, I would point out that no more attractive exhibit could be forwarded to India than a carefully selected collection os tree ferns, todeas &c in the full vigour of life. The could be utilised for decorative purposes, and at the close of the Exhibition, if not advantageously exchanged for a collection of Indian plants, they would bring the full amount of their cost by being sold with other decorations &c.

4. — I think that in the matter of dried plants &c, Baron von Mueller, Government Botanist, should be requested to render his assistance & his extensive knowledge and world wide reputation combining to enhance the value of any such collection that might be formed.

5. — The remaining suggestions made by Mr Guilfoyle I quite agree with. For purposes of exchange packages containing 50 or 60 kinds of seeds of arborescent and other plants should be formed, for distribution amongst the museums, Botanic Gardens &c of India.

6. — I may state, in conclusion, that I am thoroughly satisfied that any sum expended by your Department in the direction indicated will be amply repaid, and I would strongly recommend therefore that Mr Guilfoyly be at once authorised to take action in the matter, and that Baron von Mueller should also be invited to co-operate in making the display of Victorian vegetable products a success in every way.

div.p: Chairman Victorian Committee for the Calcutta Internl Exhibition
The Honorable A. L. Tucker M.P.

Minister of Lands
Tucker forwarded Bosisto's and Guilfoyle's letters to the Premier/Treasurer, J. Service, asking for clarification about the funds available for exhibiting at the Exhibition. [p/c is faint and the minute in reply is difficult to read.] Service forwarded the question to the Chief Secretary. In fact there is a bit of forwarding going on and the upshot seems to be that Service says (30/4) the money asked for by Bosisto needs to come out to the £5000 set aside for the Exhibition, and anyway the CSO should be able to answer this question and he wants them to do so.
No other mention of M apart from Bosisto's letter.
